content: The national strategy development is outlined in Section 1. The President, in consultation with various agencies, must develop a national strategy for combating terrorism financing and illicit finance. The strategy must be submitted to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act, with updates due by January 31, 2020, and January 31, 2022. The national strategy for combating terrorism financing and illicit finance must be submitted to Congress within specified timelines. Classified information within the strategy will be presented separately in a classified annex or as a briefing upon request by congressional committee members. Classified information within the strategy will be presented separately in a classified annex or as a briefing upon request by congressional committee members. SEC. 2. CONTENTS OF NATIONAL STRATEGY. The strategy outlined in section 1 includes evaluating current efforts to address illicit finance risks, aligning with the broader counterterrorism strategy, and setting goals for disrupting illicit finance activities in the financial sector. The strategy aims to reduce illicit finance activities in the US financial system by identifying threats, reviewing enforcement efforts, regulations, and laws, and improving detection and prosecution initiatives. Efforts are being made to improve detection and prosecution of illicit finance by ensuring timely availability of relevant data to federal departments, agencies, and financial institutions to comply with laws against illicit finance. Efforts are being made to enhance partnerships between the private financial sector and federal departments to prevent and detect illicit finance. This includes facilitating compliance with laws against illicit finance while maintaining effectiveness, and providing guidance to strengthen internal processes. The curr_chunk discusses enhancing intergovernmental cooperation to combat illicit finance through cooperative efforts between federal, state, and local officials, as well as with governments of countries and multinational institutions. It also includes trend analysis of emerging illicit finance threats. The curr_chunk focuses on trend analysis of emerging illicit finance threats, budget priorities, and technology enhancements to improve efforts to stop the financing of terrorism and other forms of illicit finance. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" includes specific committees from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "appropriate Federal banking agencies" is defined in section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The term "Federal functional regulator" is defined in the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. "Illicit finance" refers to terrorism financing, money laundering, or other illicit financing as defined by the President. "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury, and "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories.
